author: Tim O'Connell and Samantha Gee
title: American tourist left with nothing after van burglary in Nelson
text:
American tourist left with nothing after van burglary in Nelson TIM O'CONNELL AND SAMANTHA GEE Last updated 09:22, February 17 2017 MARTIN DE RUYTER 
American tourist Greg Thompson has had thousands of dollars worth of photographic equipment stolen from his vehicle while in Nelson. 
An American tourist who had $30,000 worth of gear stolen helped police find the thieves after they sent messages from his Facebook account. 
Greg Thompson said he lost his "whole life essentially" when thieves broke into his van at Rutherford carpark in Nelson. 
He went away for the weekend. When he returned to his vehicle at about 11:45pm on Tuesday, he discovered it had been broken into and everything inside taken. 
Thompson said he probably had "thirty G's worth of stuff" in the van. 
READ MORE: * Tourists targeted in knifepoint robbery in Nelson 
"I had a lot of lenses, a few camera bodies and high-end outdoor equipment - and my laptop too." 
Also among the estimated 75kg worth of possessions taken was Thompson's clothing and camping gear, which included an $800 sleeping bag which he called his "baby". 
In the early hours of Wednesday morning he noticed someone had updated his status on Facebook. The posts appeared to be trying to set him up. Thompson said the messages implied he had given his possessions away in exchange for sex. 
One post in Thompson's name said he was "so silly i got so wasted an gave all my stuff to her, now i regret it.[sic]" 
Another: "Amphetamine. it is a dangerous thing. it takes me to experience it myself to realise what control it has on you! life goes on [sic]." 
Thompson also saw messages that he hadn't written, sent from his profile to someone he didn't know. 
He had never met the woman posting on Facebook. 
The strange messages also caused alarm among his friends and family at home. 
"They were making these crazy posts and I was getting texts from overseas saying: 'what the hell's gotten into you,'?" he said. 
He printed out screenshots from his Facebook profile and showed them to Nelson police. 
Thompson thought the alleged thieves were stupid to post on his Facebook page. 
"I don't know what she was thinking." 
Glenn Russell, 43, and Ngakita Tamou, 21 appeared in Nelson District Court charged with stealing items worth $30,000 from Thompson on February 14. Russell has been remanded in custody until his next court appearance on February 17 and Tamou was remanded on bail until March 7. 
While Thompson had some of his gear returned by police, much of it was still missing and he remained hopeful it could be recovered. 
Until just a few days ago Rutherford Park was a designated freedom camping site in Nelson and would normally have been full of tourist vehicles. 
However, with campers moved on, Thompson's van was "pretty much alone", which by his own admission would have made it an easy target for thieves. 
While the car was parked in the open, he said his possessions were hidden away in backpacks under the seats. 
Thompson said he had been living in the vehicle while he was trying to sell it. While trying to stay positive despite his situation, he was unsure what his next move would be. 
"I'll have to go back to the States at some point , but I'm kind of questioning what is the point of anything – like, what are you going to take away from me now, cos' I have nothing else?" he said. 
"You can only try and live in one pair of pants for so long." 
While he had some travel insurance Thompson said it did not extend to covering his stolen equipment. 
"Everyone says: 'Oh, this is Nelson and its so nice and no-one gets robbed' – I've lived in some hard parts of the United States and I've never had my car broken into, so it kind of puts a bitter taste in your mouth," he said. - Stuff
